section_purpose: To introduce the Boolean satisfiability problem, motivate the need for machine learning-based solver selection due to structural differences in SAT instances, critique existing feature-based methods, and present the GraSS approach using graph neural networks with expert knowledge.
key_points: SAT is a fundamental NP-complete problem with applications in planning, verification, and circuit design.
Solver selection is critical because different solvers perform better on different instances, motivating data-driven approaches.
Existing methods like SATzilla use fixed-dimensional features, limiting their ability to capture complete instance information.
GraSS proposes the first GNN-based method, using literal-clause graphs with hand-designed features and positional encodings for full instance representation.
Contributions include novel architecture, features, runtime-sensitive loss, and state-of-the-art performance on benchmarks.

algorithms: SATzilla as a prior machine learning method for solver selection
Graph neural network-based method (GraSS) for solver selection
formulas: Example Boolean formula: (x1 OR NOT x2) AND (NOT x1 OR x2 OR x3) AND NOT x1
architectures: Node-specific pooling before linear classifier with softmax

dependencies: Knowledge of SAT problem and NP-completeness
Familiarity with machine learning and graph neural networks
References to related work in SAT solver selection and GNN applications in combinatorial optimization
reproducibility_notes: Representation of SAT instances as literal-clause graphs with attributes
Use of hand-designed features and positional encodings for clauses
GNN architecture with heterogeneous convolutions and pooling
Supervised training with runtime-sensitive classification loss
